title: al-Daybulī, Abū Mūsā
source_editors: Kate Fleet, Gudrun Krämer, Denis Matringe, John Nawas, and Devin J. Stewart
content: Abū Mūsā al-Daybulī (al-Dabīlī) was one of the visitors of the ecstatic Persian mystic Abū Yazīd al-Bisṭāmī (d. 261/875 or 264/877–8) who recorded his speeches. According to the Manāqib al-Bisṭāmī (“The (laudatory) biography of al-Bistami”) by Abū l-Faḍl al-Sahlajī (d. 475/1082–3), he was a follower of ʿAbd al-Raḥīm b. Yaḥyā al-Aswad al-Zāhid al-Daybulī (al-Sahlajī, Kitāb al-nūr , 54). When Abū Mūsā visited al-Bisṭāmī and heard his speeches, he extended his stay in the company of al-Bisṭāmī’s circle, and that was a benefit to him. Abū Mūsā learnt by heart al-Bisṭāmī’s speeches that were not memorised by other visitors. When he wanted to leave Abū Yazīd, he would ask his permission. One quotation (al-Sahlajī, Kitāb al-nūr , 55) from the Manāqib al-Bisṭāmī (or Kitāb al-nūr ) indicates that he was sent by al-Bisṭāmī to Armenia to preach true knowledge.

Abū Mūsā provides more than thirty speeches by al-Bisṭāmī, the majority of which are included in the Manāqib al-Bisṭāmī . A few other of al-Bisṭāmī’s citations transmitted by Abū Mūsā are found in the works of some major transmitters of Ṣūfī lore, among them: Qūt al-qulūb (“The sustenance of hearts”) by Abū Ṭālib al-Makkī (d. 386/996), a Ṣūfī author from the Arabian Peninsula who spent most of his life in Mecca, Basra, and Baghdad; al-Risāla (“The treatise (on Sufism)”) by al-Qushayrī (d. 465/1073), a major Central Asian Ṣūfī scholar and writer of manuals; Ṭabaqāt-al ṣūfiya (“Generations of the Ṣūfīs”) by al-Sulamī (d. 412/1021), a Ṣūfī exegete, hagiographer, and theorist from Nīshāpūr; Nafaḥāt al-uns (“Breezes of intimacy”) by ʿAbd al-Raḥmān Jāmī (d. 898/1492), the great mystic, scholar and writer from Herat; and Ṣifat al-ṣafwa (“The characteristic of the elect) by Ibn al-Jawzī (d. 597/1201), a Ḥanbalī jurist, exegete, preacher, and author from Baghdad.

Abū Mūsā’s own thoughts are rarely recorded in the extant Ṣūfī literature. For example, the Kitāb al-bayāḍ wa-l-sawād min khaṣāʾiṣ ḥikam al-ʿibād fī naʿt al-murīd wa-l-murād (“The black and white in the words of wisdom by bondsmen describing the seeker and the mystic quest”) by Abū l-Ḥasan al-Sīrjānī (d. c. 470/1077–8), the Persian Ṣūfī from the Kerman region, quotes short Abū Mūsā’s speeches about wisdom (ḥikma) (al-Sīrjānī, Kitāb al-bayāḍ wa-l-sawād ).

The nisba al-Daybulī indicates that Abū Mūsā’s origins were in Daybul, the port town of Sind, in present-day Pakistan, although some sources derive the nisba from Dabīl (Dvin), in the present-day Republic of Armenia. The second reading has become widespread, because it was advocated by the eminent German orientalist Helmut Ritter (d. 1971). One statement in al-Bisṭāmī’s Manāqib links Abū Mūsā with Armenia—“Oh Abū Mūsā, you are going to the Armenian land” (al-Sahlajī, Kitāb al-nūr , 55)—but this passage does not clarify his origin.
